title: Before 1 January 2021, will federal criminal charges be filed against any of the Minneapolis police officers involved in the death of George Floyd?
preds: Doesn’t look like this will happen.
Changing forecast due to passage of time.

State charges announced today. Second-degree murder is the highest one, which means it's now virtually impossible a hate crime charge would be pursued, which is the only federal case that would make sense here (that I know of). Additionally, Barr announced today that DOJ resources will be put toward investigating the irregularities in the vote totals in key states, further affirming his dedication to the current administration's agenda and all but sealing the fate of this question.

With the change in government there is a slight chance this will be addressed again however due to the media train coming to a halt on the BLM movement (for lack of a better word), unfortunately I believe this will be overlooked.
Tweaking down a bit due to passage of time and the lack of current action.

The DOJ has proven itself to be uninterested in racial or social issues. It has instead cracked down on protesters and spent months investigating the President's political opponents and defending him in several law suits. There is no way they will press charges against cops.
-7. Dropping based on time passed, still seems more likely to be a local matter and no reason Trump administration would favor this really.

If Brianna Taylor didn't get justice even at the state level, there is no way federal prosecutors are coming for the officers who killed Floyd. Barr is more concerned with stoking fear than addressing issues, Trump won't even talk about race, and the Justice Department has shown no interest in the case.
Lowering for passage of time. State charges are moving ahead.

<strike>Taking into account the possibility of a Biden appointed A.G and a sympathetic DOJ.</strike> EDIT (Sep 13 20): My mistake -- @cdob63 thank you for the correction.  I based my prediction on a false presumption.  Clearly, I should be more prudent before estimating these matters as an Australian high school student with scant understanding of the US judicial system.  Hahaha.  
Agreed, "Petits-Doigts" as you have so eloquently put, won't want his "sock-puppet" Barr to pursue this case. 
I have lowered my forecast to consensus.
Would have happened by now if it was going to.
following smarter folks than me. base rate is far lass than i allowed for originally...

Barr recently remarked that there is no issue with racism in law enforcement. It wouldn't make sense for his department to then turn around and accuse law enforcement officials of racism. Cutting my prediction in half.
The Federal grand jury would probably not wait for state charges to be adjudicated, but they're also not that likely to indict.

ok...rethinking... although there is a federal grand jury, surely federal charges can’t be publicly announced until after the state trial in March (so as not to prejudice it)???? but maybe the charges could be filed and sealed?
reducing forecast due to passage of time.

DoJ is too busy pretending to care about later police killings to go back and look at this one.  They will continue to defer to the state and local authorities. (The feds won't file charges against police officers in the later cases either, of course.  Any renegade US Attorney who went ahead and filed some charges would be sacked or reassigned within 24 hours after Fox News informs The Current Incumbent about it.  Even so, it won't go back to the Floyd case.)

I wonder if the Jacob Blake case has implications for the Floyd case, and will prompt and force the DoJ to start or enhance investigations even here, although the case seems to have different preconditions and allegations against Floyd before the alleged murder were differently, so it might not point to a "violation of civil rights" here. Time for further "investigations" on the Floyd crime scene would be rather late to find any evidence... "The U.S. Dept. of Justice confirmed it has opened a federal civil rights investigation into the shooting of Jacob Blake, the Black man who was shot by a Kenosha police officer over the weekend.
In a statement Wednesday, the agency explained the FBI will work with the state Dept. of Justice’s Division of Criminal Investigation (DCI) and state authorities to conduct the investigation."
[...]
"More than 200 federal agents from multiple agencies were also dispatched to Wisconsin." https://www.wsaw.com/2020/08/27/us-doj-confirms-civil-rights-investigation-into-jacob-blake-shooting/
https://www.justice.gov/usao-edwi/pr/us-department-justice-confirms-federal-civil-rights-investigation-shooting-mr-jacob

Even if a case will be handed over, which I doubt, will it be soon enough for
"federal criminal charges be filed against any of the Minneapolis police officers"
in 2020? I have no experience with that, so I will look for historic examples. Anyone who has an example at hand?

Bill Barr is focusing an immense amount of energy on 'Operation Legend', which just announced it had made nearly 1,500 arrests in the last few months. Over 200 of those arrested are facing federal charges according to the same report. Many are facing drug and gun charges, while federal agents have helped with almost 100 cases against those arrested for homicide. No reference is made of a single case, accusation, or arrest made regarding civil rights, which is the only way those involved in George Floyd's death may face federal criminal charges. Given the politicization of the justice department and an abundance of recent evidence, including these arrests and the nationwide crackdown on protesters, that the department is not focused on combating civil rights issues, the chances of this happening are becoming slimmer by the day. Moreover, recent reports suggest that defense attorneys are attempting to argue that Floyd overdosed on fentanyl and therefore "killed himself". While this seems like a loose case at best, it may be enough for Barr to justify not pursuing federal charges at this point.
https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/ag-barr-announces-1500-arrests-operation-legend/story?id=72470971
https://www.foxla.com/news/minneapolis-officers-attorney-alleges-george-floyd-overdosed-on-fentanyl-says-charges-should-be-dropped
I would think they would probably let this be a local matter.
I don't think there's much appetite for this politically before the election.
Give AG Barr's recent comments on BLM it seems very unlikely that criminal civil rights charges will be filed. Those are the only charges that the gov could bring.

Stepping back for passage of time, complexity of federal charging process and effect of covid on administrative procedures.  I thought (and to some extent still think) this case might be fast-tracked but should have researched the nature and history of federal prosecutions before plunging in with an overconfident guess.
Likelihood of this occurring before Jan 1st is declining.
Lowering for passage of time. These investigations can go on for years.
I haven't thought about this at all, but sticking with forecast

Federal investigations can last up to 5 years. With the politicization of both the justice department and George Floyd's murder, it is unlikely the federal law enforcement agencies are in a hurry to bring charges against the officers involved, especially since many are already facing state charges. More likely, they will invoke the state's rights argument if questioned and pass the buck down the road.
The video is incontestable and viewed globally - with Trump  in the drivers seat not likely
33 down from 40.  DOJ under Barr may ride it out...
They can claim "excited delirium" was the cause. I hope not but apparently that's the new excuse.
The video is incontestable and viewed globally.
The question lasts until the end of 2020. As such it incorporates the probability of a Biden victory. Of course, he'd have other things to worry about if he wins.
I do not think Trump wants to get involved with this.

Very little has happened over the last six weeks that suggests that prosecution will be moved from Hennepin county to federal court. 
https://www.wsj.com/articles/criminal-charges-in-george-floyds-death-set-up-legal-battle-11590791419
Many things will happen before 1 January.  This will not be among them.
After my initial knee-jerk reaction I'm finally getting with the program.
Change (-7) Reasoning: There has been no movement and nothing to disprove my previous theory that this isn't the kind of case worthy of a civil rights investigation.

Significantly downgrading this prediction. Police officers are seldom (if ever) charged with federal crimes for police brutality, even those that lead to the death of a suspect. While this case is being looked into at the federal level, the burden of proof for civil rights violations by police officers is too high and will likely result in no charges. The Trump administration fully embraces the police departments across the nation and to file charges now would be seen as appeasement and hurt his image with PD’s the nation over.
Not when Trump is tweeting Law and Order everyday and trying for an optic that the opposition do not support the police lowering.

Jumping in a little late to this bet.. You'd think so.... but i wish i could be more confident. This is why I'm betting. Per FOX News, fresh this am, dozens of rioters face federal charges.  So there's ample room to do a quid pro quo and federally charge the guy(s) who killed Floyd along with the rioters who also "went over the top" in response. https://www.foxnews.com/politics/dozens-alleged-rioters-face-federal-charges-unrest

The cowboys down at the Barr None Ranch long ago figured out this would be a no-win for them.  Minnesota will file some state charges are they won't.  If they do, DoJ will announce it's up to them and The Leader Of The Free World will unleash a nasty Twit.  If they don't, DoJ will announce it's up to them and The Leader Of The Free World will unleash a nasty Twit.  Not exactly "Profiles in Courage" in this Cabinet.
Tweaking down a bit after reconsidering the time involved in investigations.
The DOJ is already mired in so much controversy, that I expect they will stay clear and let this play out in the state court.

From WSJ article June 3: The federal criminal statute commonly used to prosecute police misconduct requires proof an officer on the job not only acted with excessive force but willfully violated someone’s constitutional rights. A misperception or poor judgment alone isn’t enough to get a conviction. Federal prosecutors have charged hundreds of law enforcement officers with civil-rights violations over the last decade. Such federal probes can take months or even years to complete. And some of the most controversial use-of-force cases never yielded criminal charges or convictions. Going below 50%. The announcement of a Federal Investigation might have been about optics and chances are that is where it stays. Intent to deprive civil rights would be hard to prove. The State Murder charge is easier here.

Changed my mind after reading more about the case. https://yubanet.com/usa/police-officers-rarely-charged-for-excessive-use-of-force-in-federal-court/ https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2020/06/17/to-ensure-justice-for-george-floyd-derek-chauvin-must-get-a-fair-trial/?slreturn=20200522115338 https://www.wsj.com/amp/articles/criminal-charges-in-george-floyds-death-set-up-legal-battle-11590791419 https://www.npr.org/2020/05/28/863630502/investigation-into-george-floyds-death-a-top-priority-for-justice-department?t=1592842025214

Bringing this more in line with the crowd. While I agree Barr is predisposed to leave this one alone, Trump may start to do some strange and desperate things in the run-up to the election to try and indicate he’s in touch with the majority outside his base. ...or not.
I believe they will wait for the state trial.
Tweaking upward. Pressure is building to get this done.

https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/06/01/i-need-to-protect-this-prosecution-minnesota-ag-keith-ellison-will-lead-george-floyd-case/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/06/02/what-just-justice-department-would-do-about-george-floyds-death/
While the law would allow Federal Charges here it is more likely it will be left with the state given the history of current Justice Department. Lowering.

The current federal investigation is for civil rights offenses which requires proof that the act was racially motivated or part of an effort to deprive Floyd of his civil rights. That is a hard standard to meet. Additionally, these kinds of charges have traditionally been used for cases in the South where police wouldn't investigate lynchings. In this case, there is a state criminal investigation already underway and I don't think Barr is that motivated to seek additional justice or to even look like he's seeking additional justice.

The charges will of course be politically motivated. Trump will not charge prior to election unless opinion polls he follows display requirement. Biden / Clinton whomever eventually gets the DNC nod will definitely if ascending to power will immediately charge the officers
Never happen with the current AG.
the feds not likely to act on this case unless DT feels it will help his re election in some way
that DA IMHO cant wait be rid of the case...

1) Weight of public opinion will inevitably affect the decision-making process.
2) The presence of video evidence.
3) Unlikely that there is any police training/instructional that teaches restraint by 4 officers including 1 with a knee on an unarmed suspect's neck.
4) The amount of force used on an unarmed suspect who was accused of using a counterfeit S$20 bill was disproportionate.
5) With his knee to Floyd's neck for over 8 minutes despite it being evident that Floyd was already in submission way before that, an intention to severely harm or even kill could be evinced - even first degree murder.  Premeditation need not be done days, or even hours, before the act.  If so, the law could be altered to suit reality.
6) This is very clearly a different situation from many other previous failed convictions of police officers using unjustified force, as there is beyond shadow of a doubt (or rather, close to that) that Floyd was unarmed, and was not going to cause any serious harm to the 4 policemen.  If anything, any of the policemen's overreaction should have been turned instead toward the crowd standing around, or the persons who Floyd was hanging around with prior to the incident, who could possibly have done something that could physically threaten the 4 policemen.
Not Before 2021-1-1. Perhaps after and under a different administration.

There is very little historical precedent for federal charges filed against police officers involved in violence against black US citizens. Such an action would require intensive investigation and scrupulous gathering of irrefutable evidence. To have these charges filed before January 1st 2021 requires high priority being assigned to this case, against many other cases. If the death of George Floyd remains the focal point of popular attention, resources may be dedicated towards a federal investigation of this case over others. However, should popular attention wane, this case may be subject to  the same slower  bureaucratic processes that all cases without high priority must undergo. Public attention to the death of George Floyd is fueled by media exposure, including mainstream television news channels as well as social media applications like twitter. It seems as if the peak of mainstream awareness for this case may have already passed. Without the threat of public ire, federal investigators will have less incentive to speed this case to the courts. Federal criminal charges against any of the Minneapolis police officers involved in the death of George Floyd may be very much delayed, if any are filed at all.

Federal charges are more likely to be suppressed by Barr than filed. In an election year, being that he's Trumps enabler, bringing charges against police officers would be an absolute disaster for Trump and Barr. And I doubt they would find a sudden semblance of humanity or good judgement between Nov 3rd and Jan 1st.

Minneapolis, with a majority of city council members committed to reforming or even dismantling the police department, will be forced to move on this case expeditiously while USAG Barr will drag his feet (at the behest of the president) as the Senate is embroiled in talks of police reforms. As the suit progresses through the Minnesota court system, Barr will announce that further involvement by the federal govt is not required since the case was being handled locally. He will then opt out filing federal charges.

The Trump administration will want to be seen to be responding to anti-racism protests, but it may conclude that local action on this front is enough. It's not clear that without the protests there would have been any appetite for a DOJ investigation, so I see this as a move designed to backstop the local moves.

It was the speed at which the Feds announced an investigation that convinced me they are all in. Checking the law: you are quite right if Prosecution in another jurisdiction is strong then no need to prosecute. 
“However, the attorney for the government’s belief that a person's conduct constitutes a federal offense and that the admissible evidence will probably be sufficient to obtain and sustain a conviction is not sufficient standing by itself to commence or recommend prosecution. The prosecution must also serve a substantial federal interest, and the prosecutor must assess whether, in his/her judgment, the person is subject to effective prosecution in another jurisdiction; and whether there exists an adequate non-criminal alternative to prosecution. It is left to the judgment of the attorney for the government to determine whether these circumstances exist. In exercising that judgment, the attorney for the government should consult JM 9-27.230, 9-27.240, 9-27.250, and 9-27.260.”
However in another part of the law it speaks about seriousness of offense and deterrence: “One factor that is obviously of primary importance is the actual or potential impact of the offense on the community and on the victim(s). The nature and seriousness of the offense may also include a consideration of national security interests.
The impact of an offense on the community in which it is committed can be measured in several ways: in terms of economic harm done to community interests; in terms of physical danger to the citizens or damage to public property; and in terms of erosion of the inhabitants' peace of mind and sense of security. In assessing the seriousness of the offense in these terms, the prosecutor may properly weigh such questions as whether the violation is technical or relatively inconsequential in nature and what the public attitude may be toward prosecution under the circumstances of the case. 
Deterrent Effect of Prosecution. Deterrence of criminal conduct, whether it be criminal activity generally or a specific type of criminal conduct, is one of the primary goals of the criminal law. This purpose should be kept in mind, particularly when deciding whether a prosecution is warranted for an offense that appears to be relatively minor; some offenses, although seemingly not of great importance by themselves, if commonly committed would have a substantial cumulative impact on the community.“
So far not able to determine base rate as not sure where to get statistics on it. 
Going to dial back some as it appears it could go either way but noting the Feds did start into an investigation.
Charges filed would most likely not be federal

There are a number of reference cases, including but certainly not limited to the murders of Eric Garner, Anthony Baez, and Rodney King. The process by which those cases were handled began with a singular state indictment, and then followed up with a federal criminal suit.   Most low to mid profile police brutality cases typically lead to no federal charges. The small data pool shows that social pressure is necessary in these situations of overt police misconduct to garner federal civil rights claims. Federal charges for the Rodney King case came only a week after the riots that led to over $1B in damage and over 60 deaths.  I believe the timing, only a week after civil unrest, signifies that the federal indictment served an indirect purpose, and that was to prevent further strife and appease vengeful and riotous groups.  In the context of George Floyd’s murder, tempers have currently simmered, and there is less pressure to pursue TANDEM charges with the state. The concerned public is content waiting for the states decision and punishment.  Federal charges will come after the state, especially if the states decision is too soft.

I believe the state case will be the focus.  If there are acquittals then feds will possibly try to take it on but that won't be this year. The only possibility might be right before the election to try to boost Trump but those aren't his supporters anyway so he won't care.  So, in the end I think not this year.
Not a chance with Trump in office

I believe that federal charges would most likely only be pressed in the event that the officers are acquitted. I think that it's quite unlikely that will occur before 2021-01-01. The political positions of the current administration and AG make me update that probability that federal charges will be filed- even in the event of an acquittal within the year- downward.
Charges at the federal level may be harder to obtain due the checks and balances of the system and the type of crime(s) committed.

1. The level of public sentiment is extremely high for police to be held accountable.
2. He will be used as a scape goat by the system to show there is accountability .
3. The video evidence is extremely compelling and conclusive.
4. Duration of time police office had his knee on Floyds next shows intent to kill.

Wondering about base rates are when the Feds decide to file civil rights violations even though the state is already proceeding with a criminal case? Is this a hate crime? I read that the Fed steps in when the state doesn't.
On the other hand, is Barr just going to do it for obvious political reasons? Think he'll wait but get credit  for saying he will and credit for restraining himself.
There will be investigations but charges will be contained to the State level, SOP for this Admin.

State charges have already been filed. Federal govt currently not interested In pursuing hate crime charges. There apparently is a federal investigation but to bring charges would be to admit that the people protesting Floyds death are justified.

This issue has sparked international movements. Video evidence clearly shows the use of unnecessary force.  Was reasonable force used? No, evidence is damning. Election year may well influence timing and strength of conviction (bail increase is one indication). If protests continue convictions will likely be brought forward to address the momentum. Murder/Manslaughter at the state level / civil rights violations at the federal level, especially if the venue isn't moved. See here:
https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/08/opinions/where-the-george-floyd-case-must-be-tried-honig/index.html
Civil Rights violation but have to research exact criminal statute.

To prove a willfullness to deprive Floyd of his rights is a high bar. The standard is beyond a reasonable doubt.  Yes the officer's knee was on his neck, but was it there to deprive floyd of life.  It resulted in the death, but was it  placed there with the intent to kill the man?  If charges are brought, the feds will need to prove the knee was placed there willingly to deprive floyd of life.  I do not believe that they will pursue a line that the knee was placed on the neck properly, but by not withdrawing it after floyd stopped struggling the action became willfull denial of rights.
Mass protests and public sentiment will continue to push for criminal charges.
Depends on status and results of state prosecution
Barr will stall this for as long as he can

I've been swayed by the elegant prose offered by @cdob63 who so concisely captures the spirit of our republic in the rationale he provides for his forecast. Some of us just don't have the gift for sensitive communication that @cdob63 posses.
I suspect that at the federal level there would be a decision not to anger the police unions and file charges given strong law and order leanings of the Trump supporters

This is a case in which the Prince Of Orange can have it both ways.  His sockpuppet A-G will put the DoJ investigation on hold and defer to the Minnesota authorities until they're done with whatever they're going to do.  If they do something, he needn't, and if they don't do anything, his charade investigation can go on until the bovines return to base.  The Leader Of The Free World can thus put on an almost believable show of doing something, while not doing anything that will alarm his dwindling base--who, by the way, will be the only ones fooled by this (or in some cases, pretending to be fooled).   It's been a tough few years for fans of real reality, although a nonstop party for fans of the tv version.  Running out of bourbon again.
Not likely with the current administration and election posturing but Trump is unpredictable if nothing else

With the Trump administration, and the current stance of POTUS as well as his current track record and values, it is highly doubtful the DOJ would file charges. However, there may be enough pressure to change this and POTUs is known for having change of hearts on a whim, leaving a small chance of a “Yes”
Base rate is 4%. Timing is also an issue—state of Minnesota is dealing with it now and likely still will be by January 1st.

Assuming he loses the election, Trump will no longer have a need to cater to his base. His administration will make a number of moves on their way out to try and put themselves on the right side of history.
Charges are easy to make, convictions hard to come by.

Current administration has not a strong record of federal civil rights charges and is not showing an incentive to change course for re-election.
Evidence of personal relationship between Flloyd and Chauvin would complicate.

I believe such charges could be filed and a conviction is theoretically possible.  However, I believe it HIGHLY unlikely that under this administration charges would be filed in this case.  Doing so would represent an astonishing about-face by the likes of Mr. Trump and Mr. Barr.
Officer already arrested and out on bail. Public outcry catastrophic if they are not found guilty

They were made this week for the last three officers. They were made last week for the primary officer.

I think it's noteworthy that the question does not refer to civil or state prosecution but to federal criminal charges. To me it seems they're the least involved party in this, however their taking action would have the most symbolic value...
I'll side with @Dillyweed and use the same argument and line of thinking.

This is an election year, so it is possible that Barr will do something to help the Trump administration look like they care. However, he also ordered the attack on the peaceful protesters in DC. Also, the Black population in general, will not be swayed by it.

If they can drag it along til after the November election, they will. Trump's base won't be happy if federal charges are brought for murder. But the officers can be charged with federal criminal charges of violating civil rights. 
As with most things in an election year, this will be another calculated risk.

Barr seems to be a friend of this phrase. "There's the old saying that the wheels of justice grind slow,"
